newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Albright proposes "friends of Cambodia" group.
newsitem.headline: Albright proposes "friends of Cambodia" group.

text.p: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Monday pressed a U.S. initiative to create a group called "friends of Cambodia" to support ASEAN efforts to resolve the political crisis there.
She said the entity would be similar to the so-called Group of Ten that was established to monitor implementation of the 1991 Paris peace accords that ended Cambodia's civil war.

During talks at the Association of South East Asian Nations meeting here, Albright said the purpose of the new group "would be to support the ASEAN (peace) initiative and to work to achieve free and fair elections in 1998."

"Throughout this process, we will insist on respect for the 1991 Paris peace accords, for the Cambodian constitution, and for the democratic process that has given the Cambodian people five years of relative peace after decades of horror and fear," she said in a statement released by the State Department.

The United States has firmly endorsed ASEAN's leadership in pursing a political settlement to the crisis in Cambodia caused when Second Prime Minister Hun Sen overthrew the first prime minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, in a bloody coup on July 6.

Washington, which has temporarily suspended aid to Cambodia, opposes Hun Sen's forcible seizure of power but has accepted the reality of his military control of the country and is pushing with ASEAN and its allies for a political solution.
ASEAN comprises Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam along with new members Burma and Laos.
